text: I'll talk about taking cloud native offline I think what I'm going to talk about is not just inherent to cloud native so hopefully it will lean into other bits of your business and stuff like that that you can take offline too One thing I probably should thank the organisers for is this therapy session they've given me where I can just vent all my frustrations over the years Hopefully it'll be constructive criticism but if not tough I'll just be focusing on some of the stuff that has annoyed me on both sides of the vendor barrier I've worked for defence companies deploying stuff and then I've been a vendor on the other side trying to sell stuff to banks and big pharma and stuff like that as well So Amazon did a little demo for me yesterday of why you might want to consider some of this stuff We've had the NPM attacks as well recently and a few other things as well so there's quite a lot of reasons why you might be wanting to do this I'm going to focus more on who I am what are the problems that I've seen what are the problems you get with air gap networks with isolating things decoupling not just isolating but removing your dependencies how might we solve them some examples mostly terrible of how I've solved them but also hopefully a demo of a couple of tools if we get time to that point as well I hope I'm not going to get sidetracked too much into anecdotes about my life but please come find me afterwards I've got lots of examples of everything I talk about that I can probably better share in a non recorded fashion Feel free to ask questions as well during the talk So who am I I'm Patrick Stevens I have spent 23 years now as a professional software engineer A large portion of that time initially 15 years I spent doing defence We provided platform as a service to all the platforms platforms in that sense ships submarines helicopters stuff like that that were deployed by UK France and Australia I then moved to working at a database company and then I moved to a very small start up that got acquired by a larger start up in the observability space So I've been on both sides of the kind of I want to use offline things and I want to sell you offline things argument I'm also a core maintainer for FluentBit So if anyone wants to talk about that as well come find me too as well And I run an open source consultancy around supporting FluentBit for enterprise as well So what problems do we have with offline isolation those kind of problems that you want to see in your business So I'm going to be talking about taking cloud native offline but focusing on that as a kind of a spectrum There's people like submarines who run a Faraday cage underwater for six nine months at a And then there's people who just want to decouple themselves from the latest AWS incident Maybe just not just pull things straight off the internet but at least have a way of mirroring fading over those kind of things And there's a big spectrum in between as well You've got banks financial service institutions you've got a lot of people who want to protect IP and maybe they just want to run more isolated networks and limit the blast radius of those networks as well You've got problems with security as well So what do you mean by security Build time supply chain security with the NPM attacks run time Do you want to check if someone's in your system Do you want to check what it's doing How's it working You've also got problems with compliance and data security So a lot of the use cases I've worked on from the selling to customer side has been more around compliance You've got federal institutions you've got financial institutions government institutions that need to satisfy some level of compliance where they isolate their networks So how do you do that And how do you support your system from running on their network And probably more importantly when stuff goes wrong because it will how do you debug your problems Not just how do I get my thing running but when something fails how do I give them enough information to debug that system and get that information back to me in a simple way as well Because honestly if you make it difficult people will chuck your stuff away and they'll never trust you again So that's my personal experience and that's certainly what I've done in the past And then time You can get everything offline if you try hard enough and spend enough money and time But this is just one part of my job during the day I just want to deploy your thing I don't want to learn how it works I don't want to figure out what the problems are taking it offline Please just give me something that works out of There's a huge spectrum of things there I'm just going to focus on the three that I figured have annoyed me the most in my career so far being on the other side and hopefully give you some pointers about mostly considering end users Who's actually going to be running this So we had end users who were 16 year olds who just joined the military They weren't database administrators You can't be teaching them this is how you shut OpenShift down I just want to turn it off and on again Those kind of questions as well So I would stress consider your end users as well Not everyone likes software Not everyone wants to learn it And certainly not everyone wants to even consider it's there They just want to buy a bit of hardware and keep it running So architecture Always a problem I don't really have any good solutions for this one The main thing I wanted to stress is the same thing again I want to evaluate your solution I want to try your solution How do I do it quickly and easily I don't want to have to learn how your entire architecture works to figure out which bits I can shop out which bits aren't important Don't put databases in when you don't need databases That's a lovely one I hate databases There's too many databases and databases always put in systems that don't need them If you're going to put a database in make sure it's a very simple one and we can remove it A key point there for architecture is make sure you're providing interfaces Make sure you're providing variation points Not giving me more dependencies that I need to install and download upgrade maintain all these other problems A big issue that we've certainly had in the past or I've seen in the past is a lot of cloud native assumes that you scale your hardware to fit whatever the software is that you're running If you need more compute you add more compute If you need to do more stuff you just scale your hardware up to fit the software needs A lot of on prem deployments are the opposite I've got a fixed amount of hardware I need to run part of your system maybe not all of it How do I do that How do I scale whatever you give me to fit on my hardware or fit in the requirements that you've given me Don't assume internet access That's a big one This comes particularly around troubleshooting and stuff like that How do you debug when stuff's gone wrong Consider when you have a problem your last customer problem that you had How would I have solved that if I couldn't get the customer to download something or the customer had to upload something to me How do I provide that One of the worst times of my career has been when we've had to debug a completely non functional platform and the vendor kept giving us more dependencies to download and put on that platform to figure out what was wrong Every time we have to download something we have to burn it to disk we have to sheep dip it we have to export it fill in a lot of paperwork It takes multiple days to do that If you're drip feeding me tiny container images just give me them all at once or give me a simple way of doing it as well The other one redaction as well There's loads of support scripts that just collect everything in your cluster and don't give you a nice way to say what is this thing that I'm going to upload as my support request or something like that Give me a way to redact some of that information and make me feel confident that you understand my needs I need to be able to know that the data I'm exporting from my platform isn't compromising our business in any way or I'm not breaking the Official Secrets Act in any way If I am I'm just not going to do it and I'm not going to use your The benefits around having a good architecture are pretty manifold It's a lot easier to run things locally It's a lot easier to stub bits out If you get rid of databases then you've got a lot more stateless workloads It's a lot easier to test them You don't have to run huge databases just to test simple things out You get so many other benefits as well It's not really a good silver bullet here I just wanted to touch on the problem Just consider how you can put variation points in your architecture to have more levers to pull when you need to scale things differently to maybe the traditional use case in the cloud Dependencies are the other humongous problem Make it easy to get them but also make it easy to update them There's lots of tools that provide you a big tarball of dependencies That's great but I don't want to be downloading multi gigs every single time Differential tars have existed for thousands of years now so at least give me ways that I can update things easily I touched on it briefly Give me a way to get all your dependencies in one go You must know what they are and if you don't then I'm not going to deploy your system so at least document the way that I can get those things and I can get them in one go I don't have to keep drip feeding them and requesting more endpoints and opening it up by security Filling out paperwork is the bane of my existence in these systems so don't make me do it more than once Support mirroring in your configurations A lot of systems don't I want to have proxies container proxies I want to have container mirrors I want to have mirrors of anything Just support it and consider it in your system It's not just for completely offline environments There's lots of enterprise environments that need internal mirrors internal proxies all this kind of support as well And you'll also have to deal with enterprise targets I'm still building CentOS 6 stuff still deploying it to large organizations that everyone in this room is using right now and custom based images Custom based images is a good one Almost every secure environment requires a custom based image You have to use a common based image that's integrated with some security platform or whatever You can't just go oh well I've just made a scratch image Here you go Just give me a way to support the custom based image as well Keep it simple and consistent If you're giving me tooling to do this I've got loads of tooling in my network I've already got an entire pipeline and ways of working and stuff like that I don't want to have to squeeze in this whole brand new way of tooling that's bleeding edge If you can give me tarballs or really simple stuff that's great because that just integrates so nicely with any scripting support whatever we've already got in there And people can understand it as well It's great having this wonderful new tool but if it makes this sort of arbitrary artifact that you can't really understand it's not very useful Try to use existing technology Not only is it proven but it works on those older targets as well It's always better and you've always got people in the company who already understand it and they're more likely to sign off on buying your system if they understand it And there's also the concerns around you get a lot of provenance attestations SBOMs all these kind of security artifacts now How can we get those and use them in our environment particularly when we start mirroring containers or changing things How do we align what we have with what you've given us to make sure those artifacts around provenance and security are there And then the last dependency that everyone forgets about licensing So I had a vendor that required our submarine to connect to their license server every three months We did not purchase that vendor for obvious reasons because I then asked them what happens if I can't get a license because I'm underwater And they said all functionality is disabled And I was like no that's not great So consider how you might support licensing Please don't do the old school approach of auditing But yeah consider how we can do licensing and configure it People want to pay for licensing I'm more than happy to pay for licenses It's not my money But how can we properly do it and manage it And then the other side of the coin that everyone forgets about documentation Almost everyone you speak to particularly if you've got a large enough budget and says I would like to take your thing but I need to deploy it in some form of isolated environment Sales will tell you yes yes of course you can do that And of course you can do it You just have to figure out how to do it yourself So it may be possible but my guiding principle about this was if it's not documented it's not supported I'm not using it Because it means not only have you not considered my use case you're not testing my use case It may break next version I'm then hamstrung with whatever I've got So prove to me you understand what I need Document as well that you work for multiple versions People aren't going to be upgrading to your latest and greatest all the time There shouldn't be a need to upgrade There should be a clear upgrade path We're only supporting from this major version to that major version Here's a migration tool whatever But at least have something in And also when I'm evaluating it give me an option to provide a complete standalone stack in less than one hour That was always my threshold as well If it took more time than that then it's just not going to be a good fit for us Obviously excluding all downloads because some of them are massive and takes ages But having a good way to get a standalone simple stack comes into architecture as well It makes it easy to test reuse and test locally iterate everything locally And then documentation side again debugging and support How are you going to support those kinds of environments What are you going to do when something goes wrong Because something will go wrong People are rubbish at deploying things with instructions so they'll deploy it wrong How do you know they've deployed it wrong These kinds of questions as well Not just failures but configuration failures as well Right so I've talked about all the problems I've seen Well some of the problems I've seen I'll try not to go into too many tangents But I just wanted to bring up some examples of good kind of tooling that we've used in the past So I've used K3S myself I know it's deployed on various platforms as well that are very isolated But we've also built products based on it I worked at startups where we didn't want to support a million different ways to deploy our project on VMs or whatever so we just wrapped our container up We only support Kubernetes and we wrapped it up into K3S with an RPM job done Now we just support a Kubernetes deployment and let K3S and their maintainers fix all our problems to some degree They've got a nice offline images tarball as well that's quite straightforward to use It can be quite big but also it works out of the box and I don't need anything else so I know it's fine Now running that database on a single node system was almost impossible Getting that database downloaded was really difficult Keeping it updated was really difficult And in the end we came across Trivi and Trivi requires a database but lets you download it as part of its setup You can just get it to download and it will include it locally on its container image if you want to package it up So that was a much more simple straightforward approach as well It's well documented easy to use I've not had any issues and I'm pretty stupid so it should be good for everyone else A long time ago back in my defense days I also worked on Stack in a Box which was an OpenShift development platform we were supposed to provide for contractors and third parties So contractors there are people other companies that we were contracting to do work A fully working development platform that was identical to our OpenShift runtime platform that was deployed on the various submarines and stuff like that So there are lots of issues there The Trivi issue came up in that as well and I did a talk on that a while back so I was just linking it there But that was quite a difficult project at the time OpenShift didn't support single node deployment We needed single node deployment so there was a lot of work with Red Hat as well around some of that Then there were some very hard requirements on the runtime platform as well like from power off to minimum safe sonar less than two minutes those kind of things So it's quite a tricky thing to do and I was pretty proud of it in the end even if maybe it was a bit of a mess of a project halfway through Then I worked for an observability startup called Kalyptia and we made a standalone version of our observability stack That was my attempt using Helm Charts essentially to provide that kind of configuration around the architecture side allowing us to support different container registries being able to configure different components of the system but also then wrapping it up so I can download all of that and give you an RPM or a DEM or whatever just to install it Because that's what all the enterprise providers want They want on the stand VMs I just want you to give me a VM a package I can just put into Puppet Chef Ansible whatever and funnel it into my system I don't want to manage another Kubernetes environment and work with Helm Charts and stuff like that So those are some examples there Some other approaches I was doing some research recently to look at some of this stuff Architecture wise particularly around configuration I'd say the standard approaches are Helm or Customize at the moment If you're not using those it's going to be hard for other people to figure out what you're doing so probably just stick with them if you can It's quite straightforward because it's just a file It's not some weird binary or anything like that I did see Microconfig but I've not really used it but it looked like an interesting approach But again I'd say if you're not using an industry standard you're making a mistake so don't make something up There's a lot of stuff there Why wasn't I just customizing that and doing that So sometimes take a little bit of a step back and look at what you've got as well And then yeah dependencies You need some way of managing all those dependencies as well You've got package downloads You might have some custom scripting You've got containers Scopia and Crane are good examples at the moment I've used Scopia quite a lot We even use it for the open source side to promote the container images and stuff like that It's a pretty good solution and it's pretty well established and well documented as well And then more recently some other solutions have come up more fully featured things for taking your entire deployment and running it in a complete offline solution without you having to do any work That's their goal It's not quite true but yeah But they're more fully featured solutions and are quite interesting as well So what is Hauler At a high level it's just a glorified tarball maker Everyone can make a tarball How do you make it How do you configure it What do you do Everyone has their favorite bike shed color for their bash scripts It's pretty good I've been playing with it the last few days and it's pretty nice It works with all the standard container native stuff But one thing that's pretty good for it is it also works with just random files like if you just need to provide some package or some specific binary or something like that Maybe it's not in a container image Not everyone's always deploying container images How do you do that So the demo yeah I just put K9S on there just as an example But it lets you pull in random files as well that potentially you need But I'm a little bit concerned with the lack of documentation How does that work Although yeah with the Rancher and K3S stuff I generally trust it to work These are open source as well I've not picked anything that's not open source So you can go validate it as well So yeah I'll show you a quick demo of that in a bit But essentially Hauler makes you a tarball you transfer it and then you can push it into whatever system you need You still need to do the deployment on the other side though which is where Zarf comes in which is a little bit different and solves a slightly different problem I think Zarf's goal is to take one cluster that you've got running online and be able to completely deploy it offline as well with nothing else The documentation is really good I'd encourage someone to go look at it as an example just of how to write documentation But they've got great examples It's a really good thing for an offline demo Hopefully I'll show you in a minute It's distro agnostic they claim So by distro they mean Kubernetes versions there So it should work on any kind of certified Kubernetes But again proof's in the pudding You'll probably find a Kubernetes distribution that's missing some standard component that it will fail on But yeah it seems to work for me You can use it for built in mirroring So you can just run it on one cluster and mirror it somewhere else So good for kind of a failover with like AWS or something like that The downside I can kind of see there is they don't really support non container artifacts So they'll support Helm charts they'll support container images anything that's in an OCI registry So potentially if you want to do that you could push anything you need into an OCI registry and mirror it that They've also got a they'll do Git mirroring as well which is quite useful I know yesterday there were concerns because AWS was down all the documentation was down to Confluence and stuff like that as well because people couldn't log in So a lot of run books and stuff like that might not be available So it might be useful to mirror that They've also got an injector approach about which so they take a cluster that has nothing in it and then they seed it with a registry But how do you push a registry image to something that doesn't have a registry So they've got an interesting approach of reconstructing a registry image from config map chunks and bootstrapping it into the cluster I'm not sure I'd ever use that in production because you have to run a cluster at that point just run a registry as well It's quite straightforward But it was quite good for the offline demos and stuff You just spin up a cluster and everything's ready to go You don't need to start pushing images to custom registries But it's worth having a look at It's quite interesting So demo time So I'm going to do a demo Everything's up on the Git repo That's where I'm running it from It's just the observability stack So kubeprom stack I think it is I can't remember what it's called With a fluent bit deployment as well So I'll show you what Hawler does and then what Zarf does as well I'll start with Zarf because it's a bit more interesting because Hawler just makes the tarball So we've got five minutes Hopefully I can do the Right so I spun up a cluster It's just a coin cluster Earlier on today just before in the previous one I created my Zarf package So that's defined by again like everything good defined by YAML that just says all the components that you want to do Let's just go show it in here because we're offline So it's just some can everyone see that by the way Yeah yeah All the different things you want to get So I've made a Git repo there just to show you And then yeah The good thing here is it takes you can see I've got two different fluent bit deployments there I've got one that I run as a daemon set and then I've got I don't know why it's indented slightly different Oh yeah there we go Daemon set to forward to an aggregator So Hawler will just collect everything you need Zarf will take your deployments and mirror them So that's why it's a slightly different approach And then yeah So earlier on today downloaded all that You get a little ZST package here It's got everything in it That's just the tarball You can open it up and have a look And then I can deploy it into the cluster Let me just get the commands So first of all there's a little bit of Zarf in it The main thing here is just initializing the Git server to show the mirrored stuff So hopefully we'll see it in a minute Oh let me turn the Wi Fi off just to prove that we're offline So we'll deploy everything for the Zarf kind of setup which includes this weird Docker registry approach of reconstructing it If it picks it up quickly enough you'll see one registry then another because it bootstraps one and then provides the other So we've done that Now we need to start pushing the So it hosted a registry and then it pushed the registry image to that registry to then run the actual registry which then hosts all the other stuff And then there's some mutating webhooks to deal with making sure your things are all pulling from the right registry and stuff like that And then we've got GitT for the internal Git server And I'll just go grab the other command which is So Zarf's really nice for if you want to do an offline demo really good because you can also get it to deploy K3S for you from scratch So it seems a nice way of making a single you know just having a tarball and you know it will run even if the Wi Fi's crap or whatever So now we're deploying GitT There we go So everything should be set up in the cluster ready to go There's GitT down the now I'll deploy the package that we made before which we can kind of see here It might take a while because it's quite large But it's basically just a load of SBOMs containers and Helm deployments So we push all these we run up the stack and you should have a completely functional solution after that So we don't need to deploy anything we don't need to do anything else It's just going Whereas Hauler's quite the opposite which is like Hauler just grabs everything you need and then it's up to you to deploy it on the other side Which to be honest is probably what you're more likely doing Zarf seems quite nice though for doing demos and things like that Or maybe for people who don't really understand Kubernetes or don't want to get involved with it as well Right so now it's installing the Helm chart And remember I've turned Wi Fi off so we haven't got anything So we're definitely offline Come on I probably should have picked a lighter weight Helm chart But it definitely worked There we go Everything starts spinning up So again I've not had to do anything I've just said deploy this tarball and off it goes and replicates the same stuff you've configured in your YAML file onto your offline solution So it might be quite useful as well if you want to package it up into your own package and stuff like that And you can remove the Zarf stuff afterwards too I've got all that there So yeah we get a Prometheus stack Now we're going to let it deploy for a bit And then if we have time we could look at the dashboard and stuff like that But we'll probably run out of time for that In fact should we move to questions while it's doing this If anyone has any Any questions Or is everyone just hungry This gentleman at so it's just a quick question about the registry So you're creating a tarball from the world environment putting it in the air at the moment and then you need to keep running the Zarf registry in order if there are like worker reboots or something in the registry Do you need to redeploy the Zarf registry in order to work completely No no So again I wouldn't use Zarf personally to deploy an offline environment just because I would want more control over what's going on But you can use it to push to your own registry and use that And you can set the registry to be HA if you really want and in cluster as well and stuff like that I probably use the Hauler approach which is more like here's all the images And again that can push them to wherever you want to push them to But Hauler is more about giving you the artifacts and then it's your responsibility to deploy them whereas Zarf seems to do the whole lot for you which is nice for offline demos but maybe isn't what you want in a completely offline solution Probably should give a shout out to the Manchester meetup as well I help host So if anyone's in Manchester and wants to come talk about cloud native stuff as well we've got one in November and be good to see more people particularly if we want to talk particularly if we want to sponsor or host we need those as well Yeah And how do you add provenance and security to that thing as well I'd also set caution as well Yeah it's great to have one thing But if you're going to do something like differential uploads or something like it might be better to make it a bit more granular For me it's more about having one process and I can do it in one go rather than maybe having I could have like a thousand tarballs I don't mind as long as I can do all of them in one go and deliver it And I noticed in both of these tools as well they start generating SBOMs for the actual components they're putting in and then you could generate an SBOM and a provenance attestation for the overall artifact as well I guess And you certainly would need that It's like you can't do oh download this thing off the internet Here you go Yeah it's fine So yeah Yeah I skipped over security because it was hard So yeah I'm curious about the training and expertise So taking for example you deploy a system on a submarine does that then require a Kubernetes administrator to run that Yeah So I think this comes into considering end users No they don't want that They don't care what they're doing and what the software is They bought a submarine The people on board are pressing buttons on the submarine and fighting and doing whatever they need to do A lot of them don't want to be database administrators OpenStack administrators So you'll find in those cases a lot of the requirements are like I can just turn it off and on again and it will work I don't need to consider Kubernetes in any way It's more about I've got a UI that I've been trained to use and this deploys things for me and stuff like that So the people on the boat generally aren't given access to infrastructure because they'll start hosting game servers and other things as well So it's very much for the engineers just to use that So the people on the boat again consider your end users We provide UIs UX approaches for I need to run this sonar system and it's made up of these components So you give them buttons start stop those kind of quite straightforward stuff But also how do I deal with self healing How do I tell you when stuff's gone wrong in a good way Not just media alerts that SREs just ignore and stuff like that If something's important tell me about it If it's not important what are you doing So yeah And they have very strong requirements about turning things off and minimum boot times and stuff like that So you have to consider other approaches as well The minimum boot times is impossible to meet with Kubernetes clusters generally So we ended up doing stuff where we'd run a fixed composed stack or something like that to give you enough software to keep running but then bring everything else up in the background and switch back over to it So you could run degraded but at least you could see where you're going So yeah it's kind of yeah So yeah end user concerns It's like yeah not everyone's database administrator not everyone's Kubernetes administrator and they certainly don't want to be So I don't think I answered your question I just said yeah we don't do that Feel free to find me afterwards and I can give you more anecdotes and Wonderful In that case let's go for some lunch But thank you again to Patrick Thank you

segments.text: I'll talk about taking cloud native offline I think what I'm going to talk about is not just inherent to cloud native so hopefully it will lean into other bits of your business and stuff like that that you can take offline too

One thing I probably should thank the organisers for is this therapy session they've given me where I can just vent all my frustrations over the years Hopefully it'll be constructive criticism but if not tough

I'll just be focusing on some of the stuff that has annoyed me on both sides of the vendor barrier I've worked for defence companies deploying stuff and then I've been a vendor on the other side trying to sell stuff to banks and big pharma and stuff like that as well

So Amazon did a little demo for me yesterday of why you might want to consider some of this stuff We've had the NPM attacks as well recently and a few other things as well so there's quite a lot of reasons why you might be wanting to do this

I'm going to focus more on who I am what are the problems that I've seen what are the problems you get with air gap networks with isolating things decoupling not just isolating but removing your dependencies how might we solve them some examples mostly terrible of how I've solved them but also hopefully a demo of a couple of tools if we get time to that point as well

I hope I'm not going to get sidetracked too much into anecdotes about my life but please come find me afterwards I've got lots of examples of everything I talk about that I can probably better share in a non recorded fashion Feel free to ask questions as well during the talk

So who am I I'm Patrick Stevens I have spent 23 years now as a professional software engineer A large portion of that time initially 15 years I spent doing defence We provided platform as a service to all the platforms platforms in that sense ships submarines helicopters stuff like that that were deployed by UK France and Australia

I then moved to working at a database company and then I moved to a very small start up that got acquired by a larger start up in the observability space So I've been on both sides of the kind of I want to use offline things and I want to sell you offline things argument
I'm also a core maintainer for FluentBit So if anyone wants to talk about that as well come find me too as well And I run an open source consultancy around supporting FluentBit for enterprise as well
So what problems do we have with offline isolation those kind of problems that you want to see in your business
So I'm going to be talking about taking cloud native offline but focusing on that as a kind of a spectrum There's people like submarines who run a Faraday cage underwater for six nine months at a

And then there's people who just want to decouple themselves from the latest AWS incident Maybe just not just pull things straight off the internet but at least have a way of mirroring fading over those kind of things

And there's a big spectrum in between as well You've got banks financial service institutions you've got a lot of people who want to protect IP and maybe they just want to run more isolated networks and limit the blast radius of those networks as well

You've got problems with security as well So what do you mean by security Build time supply chain security with the NPM attacks run time Do you want to check if someone's in your system Do you want to check what it's doing How's it working

You've also got problems with compliance and data security So a lot of the use cases I've worked on from the selling to customer side has been more around compliance You've got federal institutions you've got financial institutions government institutions that need to satisfy some level of compliance where they isolate their networks

So how do you do that And how do you support your system from running on their network And probably more importantly when stuff goes wrong because it will how do you debug your problems Not just how do I get my thing running but when something fails how do I give them enough information to debug that system and get that information back to me in a simple way as well

Because honestly if you make it difficult people will chuck your stuff away and they'll never trust you again So that's my personal experience and that's certainly what I've done in the past And then time You can get everything offline if you try hard enough and spend enough money and time But this is just one part of my job during the day I just want to deploy your thing I don't want to learn how it works I don't want to figure out what the problems are taking it offline Please just give me something that works out of

There's a huge spectrum of things there I'm just going to focus on the three that I figured have annoyed me the most in my career so far being on the other side and hopefully give you some pointers about mostly considering end users Who's actually going to be running this

So we had end users who were 16 year olds who just joined the military They weren't database administrators You can't be teaching them this is how you shut OpenShift down I just want to turn it off and on again Those kind of questions as well So I would stress consider your end users as well Not everyone likes software Not everyone wants to learn it And certainly not everyone wants to even consider it's there They just want to buy a bit of hardware and keep it running

So architecture Always a problem I don't really have any good solutions for this one The main thing I wanted to stress is the same thing again I want to evaluate your solution I want to try your solution How do I do it quickly and easily I don't want to have to learn how your entire architecture works to figure out which bits I can shop out which bits aren't important Don't put databases in when you don't need databases That's a lovely one I hate databases

There's too many databases and databases always put in systems that don't need them If you're going to put a database in make sure it's a very simple one and we can remove it A key point there for architecture is make sure you're providing interfaces Make sure you're providing variation points Not giving me more dependencies that I need to install and download upgrade maintain all these other problems

A big issue that we've certainly had in the past or I've seen in the past is a lot of cloud native assumes that you scale your hardware to fit whatever the software is that you're running If you need more compute you add more compute If you need to do more stuff you just scale your hardware up to fit the software needs

A lot of on prem deployments are the opposite I've got a fixed amount of hardware I need to run part of your system maybe not all of it How do I do that How do I scale whatever you give me to fit on my hardware or fit in the requirements that you've given me

Don't assume internet access That's a big one This comes particularly around troubleshooting and stuff like that How do you debug when stuff's gone wrong Consider when you have a problem your last customer problem that you had How would I have solved that if I couldn't get the customer to download something or the customer had to upload something to me How do I provide that

One of the worst times of my career has been when we've had to debug a completely non functional platform and the vendor kept giving us more dependencies to download and put on that platform to figure out what was wrong Every time we have to download something we have to burn it to disk we have to sheep dip it we have to export it fill in a lot of paperwork It takes multiple days to do that

If you're drip feeding me tiny container images just give me them all at once or give me a simple way of doing it as well The other one redaction as well There's loads of support scripts that just collect everything in your cluster and don't give you a nice way to say what is this thing that I'm going to upload as my support request or something like that Give me a way to redact some of that information and make me feel confident that you understand my needs

I need to be able to know that the data I'm exporting from my platform isn't compromising our business in any way or I'm not breaking the Official Secrets Act in any way If I am I'm just not going to do it and I'm not going to use your

The benefits around having a good architecture are pretty manifold It's a lot easier to run things locally It's a lot easier to stub bits out If you get rid of databases then you've got a lot more stateless workloads It's a lot easier to test them You don't have to run huge databases just to test simple things out You get so many other benefits as well

It's not really a good silver bullet here I just wanted to touch on the problem Just consider how you can put variation points in your architecture to have more levers to pull when you need to scale things differently to maybe the traditional use case in the cloud

Dependencies are the other humongous problem Make it easy to get them but also make it easy to update them There's lots of tools that provide you a big tarball of dependencies That's great but I don't want to be downloading multi gigs every single time Differential tars have existed for thousands of years now so at least give me ways that I can update things easily

I touched on it briefly Give me a way to get all your dependencies in one go You must know what they are and if you don't then I'm not going to deploy your system so at least document the way that I can get those things and I can get them in one go I don't have to keep drip feeding them and requesting more endpoints and opening it up by security Filling out paperwork is the bane of my existence in these systems so don't make me do it more than once

Support mirroring in your configurations A lot of systems don't I want to have proxies container proxies I want to have container mirrors I want to have mirrors of anything Just support it and consider it in your system It's not just for completely offline environments There's lots of enterprise environments that need internal mirrors internal proxies all this kind of support as well

And you'll also have to deal with enterprise targets I'm still building CentOS 6 stuff still deploying it to large organizations that everyone in this room is using right now and custom based images Custom based images is a good one Almost every secure environment requires a custom based image You have to use a common based image that's integrated with some security platform or whatever
You can't just go oh well I've just made a scratch image Here you go Just give me a way to support the custom based image as well

Keep it simple and consistent If you're giving me tooling to do this I've got loads of tooling in my network I've already got an entire pipeline and ways of working and stuff like that I don't want to have to squeeze in this whole brand new way of tooling that's bleeding edge

If you can give me tarballs or really simple stuff that's great because that just integrates so nicely with any scripting support whatever we've already got in there And people can understand it as well It's great having this wonderful new tool but if it makes this sort of arbitrary artifact that you can't really understand it's not very useful

Try to use existing technology Not only is it proven but it works on those older targets as well It's always better and you've always got people in the company who already understand it and they're more likely to sign off on buying your system if they understand it

And there's also the concerns around you get a lot of provenance attestations SBOMs all these kind of security artifacts now How can we get those and use them in our environment particularly when we start mirroring containers or changing things How do we align what we have with what you've given us to make sure those artifacts around provenance and security are there

And then the last dependency that everyone forgets about licensing So I had a vendor that required our submarine to connect to their license server every three months We did not purchase that vendor for obvious reasons because I then asked them what happens if I can't get a license because I'm underwater And they said all functionality is disabled

And I was like no that's not great So consider how you might support licensing Please don't do the old school approach of auditing But yeah consider how we can do licensing and configure it People want to pay for licensing I'm more than happy to pay for licenses It's not my money But how can we properly do it and manage it

And then the other side of the coin that everyone forgets about documentation Almost everyone you speak to particularly if you've got a large enough budget and says I would like to take your thing but I need to deploy it in some form of isolated environment Sales will tell you yes yes of course you can do that And of course you can do it You just have to figure out how to do it yourself

So it may be possible but my guiding principle about this was if it's not documented it's not supported I'm not using it Because it means not only have you not considered my use case you're not testing my use case It may break next version I'm then hamstrung with whatever I've got

So prove to me you understand what I need Document as well that you work for multiple versions People aren't going to be upgrading to your latest and greatest all the time There shouldn't be a need to upgrade There should be a clear upgrade path We're only supporting from this major version to that major version Here's a migration tool whatever But at least have something in

And also when I'm evaluating it give me an option to provide a complete standalone stack in less than one hour That was always my threshold as well If it took more time than that then it's just not going to be a good fit for us

Obviously excluding all downloads because some of them are massive and takes ages But having a good way to get a standalone simple stack comes into architecture as well It makes it easy to test reuse and test locally iterate everything locally

And then documentation side again debugging and support How are you going to support those kinds of environments What are you going to do when something goes wrong Because something will go wrong People are rubbish at deploying things with instructions so they'll deploy it wrong How do you know they've deployed it wrong These kinds of questions as well Not just failures but configuration failures as well

Right so I've talked about all the problems I've seen Well some of the problems I've seen I'll try not to go into too many tangents But I just wanted to bring up some examples of good kind of tooling that we've used in the past

So I've used K3S myself I know it's deployed on various platforms as well that are very isolated But we've also built products based on it I worked at startups where we didn't want to support a million different ways to deploy our project on VMs or whatever so we just wrapped our container up We only support Kubernetes and we wrapped it up into K3S with an RPM job done Now we just support a Kubernetes deployment and let K3S and their maintainers fix all our problems to some degree
They've got a nice offline images tarball as well that's quite straightforward to use It can be quite big but also it works out of the box and I don't need anything else so I know it's fine

Now running that database on a single node system was almost impossible Getting that database downloaded was really difficult Keeping it updated was really difficult And in the end we came across Trivi and Trivi requires a database but lets you download it as part of its setup You can just get it to download and it will include it locally on its container image if you want to package it up So that was a much more simple straightforward approach as well
It's well documented easy to use I've not had any issues and I'm pretty stupid so it should be good for everyone else

A long time ago back in my defense days I also worked on Stack in a Box which was an OpenShift development platform we were supposed to provide for contractors and third parties So contractors there are people other companies that we were contracting to do work

A fully working development platform that was identical to our OpenShift runtime platform that was deployed on the various submarines and stuff like that So there are lots of issues there The Trivi issue came up in that as well and I did a talk on that a while back so I was just linking it there
But that was quite a difficult project at the time OpenShift didn't support single node deployment We needed single node deployment so there was a lot of work with Red Hat as well around some of that

Then there were some very hard requirements on the runtime platform as well like from power off to minimum safe sonar less than two minutes those kind of things So it's quite a tricky thing to do and I was pretty proud of it in the end even if maybe it was a bit of a mess of a project halfway through

Then I worked for an observability startup called Kalyptia and we made a standalone version of our observability stack That was my attempt using Helm Charts essentially to provide that kind of configuration around the architecture side allowing us to support different container registries being able to configure different components of the system but also then wrapping it up so I can download all of that and give you an RPM or a DEM or whatever just to install it

Because that's what all the enterprise providers want They want on the stand VMs I just want you to give me a VM a package I can just put into Puppet Chef Ansible whatever and funnel it into my system I don't want to manage another Kubernetes environment and work with Helm Charts and stuff like that

So those are some examples there Some other approaches I was doing some research recently to look at some of this stuff Architecture wise particularly around configuration I'd say the standard approaches are Helm or Customize at the moment If you're not using those it's going to be hard for other people to figure out what you're doing so probably just stick with them if you can

It's quite straightforward because it's just a file It's not some weird binary or anything like that I did see Microconfig but I've not really used it but it looked like an interesting approach But again I'd say if you're not using an industry standard you're making a mistake so don't make something up There's a lot of stuff there

Why wasn't I just customizing that and doing that So sometimes take a little bit of a step back and look at what you've got as well And then yeah dependencies You need some way of managing all those dependencies as well You've got package downloads You might have some custom scripting You've got containers Scopia and Crane are good examples at the moment I've used Scopia quite a lot We even use it for the open source side to promote the container images and stuff like that

It's a pretty good solution and it's pretty well established and well documented as well And then more recently some other solutions have come up more fully featured things for taking your entire deployment and running it in a complete offline solution without you having to do any work That's their goal It's not quite true but yeah

But they're more fully featured solutions and are quite interesting as well So what is Hauler At a high level it's just a glorified tarball maker Everyone can make a tarball How do you make it How do you configure it What do you do Everyone has their favorite bike shed color for their bash scripts

It's pretty good I've been playing with it the last few days and it's pretty nice It works with all the standard container native stuff But one thing that's pretty good for it is it also works with just random files like if you just need to provide some package or some specific binary or something like that Maybe it's not in a container image Not everyone's always deploying container images How do you do that
So the demo yeah I just put K9S on there just as an example But it lets you pull in random files as well that potentially you need

But I'm a little bit concerned with the lack of documentation How does that work Although yeah with the Rancher and K3S stuff I generally trust it to work These are open source as well I've not picked anything that's not open source So you can go validate it as well

So yeah I'll show you a quick demo of that in a bit But essentially Hauler makes you a tarball you transfer it and then you can push it into whatever system you need You still need to do the deployment on the other side though which is where Zarf comes in which is a little bit different and solves a slightly different problem

I think Zarf's goal is to take one cluster that you've got running online and be able to completely deploy it offline as well with nothing else The documentation is really good I'd encourage someone to go look at it as an example just of how to write documentation But they've got great examples It's a really good thing for an offline demo Hopefully I'll show you in a

minute It's distro agnostic they claim So by distro they mean Kubernetes versions there So it should work on any kind of certified Kubernetes But again proof's in the pudding You'll probably find a Kubernetes distribution that's missing some standard component that it will fail on But yeah it seems to work for me

You can use it for built in mirroring So you can just run it on one cluster and mirror it somewhere else So good for kind of a failover with like AWS or something like that The downside I can kind of see there is they don't really support non container artifacts So they'll support Helm charts they'll support container images anything that's in an OCI registry So potentially if you want to do that you could push anything you need into an OCI registry and mirror it that

They've also got a they'll do Git mirroring as well which is quite useful I know yesterday there were concerns because AWS was down all the documentation was down to Confluence and stuff like that as well because people couldn't log in So a lot of run books and stuff like that might not be available So it might be useful to mirror that

They've also got an injector approach about which so they take a cluster that has nothing in it and then they seed it with a registry But how do you push a registry image to something that doesn't have a registry So they've got an interesting approach of reconstructing a registry image from config map chunks and bootstrapping it into the

cluster I'm not sure I'd ever use that in production because you have to run a cluster at that point just run a registry as well It's quite straightforward But it was quite good for the offline demos and stuff You just spin up a cluster and everything's ready to go You don't need to start pushing images to custom registries But it's worth having a look at It's quite interesting

So demo time So I'm going to do a demo Everything's up on the Git repo That's where I'm running it from It's just the observability stack So kubeprom stack I think it is I can't remember what it's called With a fluent bit deployment as well So I'll show you what Hawler does and then what Zarf does as well I'll start with Zarf because it's a bit more interesting because Hawler just makes the tarball So we've got five minutes Hopefully I can do the

Right so I spun up a cluster It's just a coin cluster Earlier on today just before in the previous one I created my Zarf package So that's defined by again like everything good defined by YAML that just says all the components that you want to do Let's just go show it in here because we're offline

So it's just some can everyone see that by the way Yeah yeah All the different things you want to get So I've made a Git repo there just to show you And then yeah The good thing here is it takes you can see I've got two different fluent bit deployments there I've got one that I run as a daemon set and then I've got I don't know why it's indented slightly different Oh yeah there we go Daemon set to forward to an aggregator

So Hawler will just collect everything you need Zarf will take your deployments and mirror them So that's why it's a slightly different approach And then yeah So earlier on today downloaded all that You get a little ZST package here It's got everything in it That's just the tarball You can open it up and have a look

And then I can deploy it into the cluster Let me just get the commands So first of all there's a little bit of Zarf in it The main thing here is just initializing the Git server to show the mirrored stuff So hopefully we'll see it in a minute Oh let me turn the Wi Fi off just to prove that we're offline

So we'll deploy everything for the Zarf kind of setup which includes this weird Docker registry approach of reconstructing it If it picks it up quickly enough you'll see one registry then another because it bootstraps one and then provides the other So we've done that Now we need to start pushing the

So it hosted a registry and then it pushed the registry image to that registry to then run the actual registry which then hosts all the other stuff And then there's some mutating webhooks to deal with making sure your things are all pulling from the right registry and stuff like that

And then we've got GitT for the internal Git server And I'll just go grab the other command which is So Zarf's really nice for if you want to do an offline demo really good because you can also get it to deploy K3S for you from scratch So it seems a nice way of making a single you know just having a tarball and you know it will run even if the Wi Fi's crap or whatever
So now we're deploying GitT There we go So everything should be set up in the cluster ready to go There's GitT down the
now I'll deploy the package that we made before which we can kind of see here It might take a while because it's quite large But it's basically just a load of SBOMs containers and Helm deployments
So we push all these we run up the stack and you should have a completely functional solution after that So we don't need to deploy anything we don't need to do anything else It's just going

Whereas Hauler's quite the opposite which is like Hauler just grabs everything you need and then it's up to you to deploy it on the other side Which to be honest is probably what you're more likely doing Zarf seems quite nice though for doing demos and things like that Or maybe for people who don't really understand Kubernetes or don't want to get involved with it as well
Right so now it's installing the Helm chart And remember I've turned Wi Fi off so we haven't got anything So we're definitely offline Come on I probably should have picked a lighter weight Helm chart

But it definitely worked There we go Everything starts spinning up So again I've not had to do anything I've just said deploy this tarball and off it goes and replicates the same stuff you've configured in your YAML file onto your offline solution

So it might be quite useful as well if you want to package it up into your own package and stuff like that And you can remove the Zarf stuff afterwards too I've got all that there So yeah we get a Prometheus stack Now we're going to let it deploy for a bit And then if we have time we could look at the dashboard and stuff like that But we'll probably run out of time for that
In fact should we move to questions while it's doing this If anyone has any
Any questions Or is everyone just hungry
This gentleman at

so it's just a quick question about the registry So you're creating a tarball from the world environment putting it in the air at the moment and then you need to keep running the Zarf registry in order if there are like worker reboots or something in the registry Do you need to redeploy the Zarf registry in order to work completely

No no So again I wouldn't use Zarf personally to deploy an offline environment just because I would want more control over what's going on But you can use it to push to your own registry and use that And you can set the registry to be HA if you really want and in cluster as well and stuff like that

I probably use the Hauler approach which is more like here's all the images And again that can push them to wherever you want to push them to But Hauler is more about giving you the artifacts and then it's your responsibility to deploy them whereas Zarf seems to do the whole lot for you which is nice for offline demos but maybe isn't what you want in a completely offline solution

Probably should give a shout out to the Manchester meetup as well I help host So if anyone's in Manchester and wants to come talk about cloud native stuff as well we've got one in November and be good to see more people particularly if we want to talk particularly if we want to sponsor or host we need those as well

Yeah And how do you add provenance and security to that thing as well I'd also set caution as well Yeah it's great to have one thing But if you're going to do something like differential uploads or something like it might be better to make it a bit more granular

For me it's more about having one process and I can do it in one go rather than maybe having I could have like a thousand tarballs I don't mind as long as I can do all of them in one go and deliver it And I noticed in both of these tools as well they start generating SBOMs for the actual components they're putting in and then you could generate an SBOM and a provenance attestation for the overall artifact as well I
guess And you certainly would need that It's like you can't do oh download this thing off the internet Here you go Yeah it's fine So yeah Yeah I skipped over security because it was hard So yeah
I'm curious about the training and expertise So taking for example you deploy a system on a submarine does that then require a Kubernetes administrator to run that

Yeah So I think this comes into considering end users No they don't want that They don't care what they're doing and what the software is They bought a submarine The people on board are pressing buttons on the submarine and fighting and doing whatever they need to do A lot of them don't want to be database administrators OpenStack administrators

So you'll find in those cases a lot of the requirements are like I can just turn it off and on again and it will work I don't need to consider Kubernetes in any way It's more about I've got a UI that I've been trained to use and this deploys things for me and stuff like that

So the people on the boat generally aren't given access to infrastructure because they'll start hosting game servers and other things as well So it's very much for the engineers just to use that So the people on the boat again consider your end users We provide UIs UX approaches for I need to run this sonar system and it's made up of these

components So you give them buttons start stop those kind of quite straightforward stuff But also how do I deal with self healing How do I tell you when stuff's gone wrong in a good way Not just media alerts that SREs just ignore and stuff like that If something's important tell me about it If it's not important what are you doing

So yeah And they have very strong requirements about turning things off and minimum boot times and stuff like that So you have to consider other approaches as well The minimum boot times is impossible to meet with Kubernetes clusters generally So we ended up doing stuff where we'd run a fixed composed stack or something like that to give you enough software to keep running but then bring everything else up in the background and switch back over to it

So you could run degraded but at least you could see where you're going So yeah it's kind of yeah So yeah end user concerns It's like yeah not everyone's database administrator not everyone's Kubernetes administrator and they certainly don't want to be So I don't think I answered your question I just said yeah we don't do that
